subject: Re: [junit] Cannot use @Rule in Scala
msgSnippet: ... Yes, a method of the same as the variable is declared public. eg, @Rule val foo = ... Will result in a public method foo() So I suppose
messageBody:
David Saff wrote:
>
> I assume then that some public accessor method gets generated for the
> field?
>

Yes, a method of the same as the variable is declared public. eg,

@Rule val foo = ...

Will result in a public method foo()

So I suppose BlockJUnit4ClassRunner#rules, ruleFields, createRules, could
be overriden to use FrameworkMethod. While that would not require classpath
hack I'm currently using to override BlockJUnit4ClassRunner, it would still
require putting a @RunWith annotation on every test, no?

It would be so much nicer if junit could be configurable without having to
pollute all the tests with this implementation detail. Having said that I'm
not sure on what approach would be appropriate and lightweight to
extend/modify the internals of junit in this way.

But why is it necessary or even good to require @Rule fields to be public?

-barry
